Goodnight. Thanks for a really fabulous evening (sarcastic).
Yes I'm upset, can't you tell?
I'm really, really sorry I told you that.
Well stop being such a baby.
You're a baby!
Hi George.
Noo, thanks.
Just gonna return some of your things that were in my house.
I know.
I'm waiting.
Yeah I got your fins. You got my poker chips?
They're next to the fins. You got my cards?
All right and that just about... does it.
Okay, welp... see you around.
All right, let's go, I give you half an hour.
Come on!
Look, Jerry, we have to have sex to save the friendship.
You know I'm a little hungry. You wouldn't happen to have any of that mango left?
She was probably joking.
She didn't have any?
(raising hand) She faked 'em all.
Well so she faked 'em, so what?
You know I heard her screaming from my apartment? She woke me up a few times.
Yeah I could have helped you out.
I could have given you some pointers. I know how to press those buttons buddy.
Aaaaah.
Giddy-up.
You know, I faked it.
Yeah.
Well you know, if it's enough already and I just wanna get some sleep.
It's terrible!
Yeah, of course I got it at Joe's.
You know what I'm gonna do? (heading for the door) I'm gonna return this.
Jerry this peach is sub par.
I want restitution.
Because it's no good.
It's still your fruit, you gotta stand behind your fruit.
So...
You know this whole place is going vrrrrrrrrrrrrt, downhill. I could have come in here last week with a bad plum but I let it go.
Oh now you don't want my business.
But what am I gonna do for fruit?
Hey.
Hey listen, if I give you money would you go out and get me some fruit?
Well I got banned from the store I can't go back in there now.
Well you know, we had a fight over the peach and uh well Joe doesn't want my business.
Jerry, what am I gonna do for fruit?

The supermarket? That's impossible! They don't have a decent piece of fruit at the supermarket. The apples are mealy, the oranges are dry. I don't know what's going on with the Papayas! Jerry you gotta go to Joe's, you gotta get me some fruit!
Alright look I'm gonna make you a fruit list, all right?
All right now here's the list. (hands Jerry the list)
I like mangos.
Well they gotta be soft.
Not too soft. Better too hard than too soft.
Yeah now get the ones that are red on the inside.
Oh! And get some plantains. (grabs the list to write them down)
Yeah.
It's part of the banana family. It's a delicacy.
Yes! Oh look at this, these mangos are beautiful! Oh these are beautiful, (smells them) you did good George.
This mango is delicious!
I only got hundreds.
Come on, come on, we're gonna pay you! Here have some mango.
Come on, take some. It's good.
Ya.
Mmm.
Ya I told you.
Want some mango?
Oh, it won't be for that long.
Hey, my parents are just as crazy as your parents.
My father has never thrown anything out. Ever!
My mother has never set foot in a natural body of water.
A smirk?
I told you I'd lend you the money for the rent.
(Stopping the notion) What's that?
(quietly) Hello, Mrs. Costanza.
Fine, Mrs. Costanza. (Attempts to get Estelle to laugh) Hey, I got a terrific joke for you..
No, no. It-It's really funny. There's these two guys-
(setting down a box) No thanks.
I really don't eat it.
I don't know if I'd feel comfortable handing out bologna sandwiches in the building..
Well, I guess we'll be going.. (Heads for the door)
Yeah.
Oh, Elaine and I are going out to dinner with Kramer and his new girlfriend.
Yeah, You can't believe this woman. She's one of those low-talkers. You can't hear a word she's saying! You're always going 'excuse me?', 'what was that?'
Yeah, take it easy. (Leaves)
Right.
Well..
Excuse me?
Yeah.. yeah.
Puffy.
Yeah, that's right!
(Points at Elaine) And the indigent.
Sure.
Uh-huh.
Yep..
(Shrugs) I - I don't get it.
What is it?
They're hands!
(Gets up, and displays his own hands) Well, what about my hands? I don't see how your hands are any better than my hands.
Well, that's what comes from avoiding manual labor your whole life.
It's just like in the movies.
Hey.
(Explaining) George has become a hand model.
Yes.
Oven mitts?
Alright. (Jerry opens the door for George)
Uh-huh.. (Finally realizes what Kramer said, he looks up) Since I said what?
What are you talking about?
(Goes up to it) This?
I agreed to wear this?!
But, when did I do that?
What are you, crazy?!
I don't know! I couldn't understand a word she was saying! I was just nodding!
Where I go? You mean she was asking me to wear this ridiculous shirt on national TV, and I said 'Yes'?!
But, I - I didn't know what she was talking about. I couldn't hear her!
I - I can't wear this puffy shirt on TV! I mean, look at it! It looks ridiculous!
They're making these?
(Like a little kid) But, I don't want to be a pirate!
(Resisting) Kramer, how am I gonna wear this?! I-I can't wear this!

(Obviously mad at the situation he's in) 'Why am I wearing is now?? I'll tell you why I'm wearing it now - because the lowtalker asked me to, that's why! And I said 'yes'. Do you know why? Because I couldn't HEAR her!
When we were at dinner, when Kramer went to the bathroom.
(Yelling out) Of course not! Nobody hears anything when this woman speaks!
(Arms out, complaining) I have to wear it! The woman has orders for this shirt based on me wearing it on TV.. they're producing them as we speak!
(Mumbling out) Thank you, Bryant.
(Looking down at the shirt; mumbling) Oh, thank you.
Yeah, it's a puffy shirt.
(Nervous laughter) Yeah.. like a pirate.. (Attempting to get on another subject) Anyway, ah, you know, we're hoping to, um, raise enough money.. with this.. uh..
Uh-huh, yeah. (Smiling, nodding, clearly wanting Bryant to shut up)
(Losing it, mad) Look, it's not my shirt.
What's the difference? I agreed to wear it. It's - it's a puffy shirt. I feel ridiculous in it, and I think it's the stupidest shirt I've ever seen, to be perfectly honest with you. (Nodding)
(Pointing off screen, nodding) THAT I heard.
Oh, just keep your voice down. Everyone can hear you.
(Reasoning) You know, if you talked this loud to begin with, I wouldn't be in this costume in the first place!
Yeah.

(Pointing out) It didn't do me any good either! That benefit was the worst show I ever did. Some of those heckles were really uncalled for: "Avast ye matey" - what the hell does that mean?! "20 degrees off the starboard side - the Spanish Galleon!" - there's no comeback for that!
Really? What happened?
What happened with all the shirts?
(While digging in his pocket for some money, he looks over the shirts one last time) You know, it's really not a bad looking shirt..
I can't believe this.
How can I do this? How can I move back in with those people? Please, tell me. They're insane. You know that.
How can you compare you parents to my parents?!
My father wears his sneakers in the pool! Sneakers!
(Showing Jerry up) Listen carefully. My mother has never laughed. Ever. Not a giggle, not a chuckle, not a tee-hee.. never went 'Ha!'
Maybe!.. And I'm moving back in there!
No, no, no, no. Borrowing money from a friend is like having sex. It just completely changes the relationship.
I don't want to! I'm outta money! I got 714 dollars left in the bank.
(Sarcastic) Yeah, yeah. I'm gonna move in with him. He doesn't even let you use the toilet!
(Sincerely) Thank you.. I, uh.. that might not work out.
(Annoyed) There's more.
Bologna?! No one eats bologna anymore!
(Muttering) No, that's it.
(Runs over to him, not wanting him to leave) What? You're going?
Wha - what are you doing later?
Really?
Yeah.. may - maybe I'll meet ya?
(Mutters) Oh.. okay.. talk to you later.
Oh, my God.. (Buries his face into his hands)
(Studying the salt shaker) I'm not taking a civil service test.
Yes, I've seen a silver dollar.
To do what?! Work in a post office? Is that what you want me to do?
I'm a college graduate. You want me to be a mailman?
I don't know. I do know that I have some kind of a talent - something to offer. I just don't know what it is yet!
(Looks fed up with his parents) Oh my God..
(Needing to get away from his parents, he gets up) I need some air..
(Walks off) I got a lot of thinking to do.
Oh, I'm sorry. I'm terribly sorry.. (Bends down, and starts picking up her things)
(Stuttering) I, I, I, .. here, let me - let me help you..
It - it's just that I'm here with my parents, and my mother wants me to take a civil service test - and to tell you the truth, I don't even think I'd pass it.. So..
What?
What about them?
They are?
Hand modeling? (Shakes his head 'No')
Me neither!
I don't know.
This woman just set me up for a job!

What, are you kidding? (Points at the flaws of Jerry's hands) The knuckles are all out of proportion. you got hair over there - where do you get off comparing your hands to my hands?! This is a one-in-a-million hand. (Points to his own hand)
This is it! It happened to me, Jerry! I was sitting in the restaurant, the two nut jobs were talking - I couldn't take it any more. I got up, and (Makes a noise) I bop into this woman..
OH!!!! What are you, crazy?! Are you, crazy?!
You coulda damaged my hand!
(Defensively) You can look at them, but do NOT touch them. (Holds them out)
(Takes two oven mitts from his back pack) Alright, (puts them on) I gotta get going.
(Embarrassed) That's all I could find. (A moment passes) Would you mind getting the door?
Thank you very much. (Walks out)
(Snaps, then points to the coffee table) Hand me an Emory board.
(To Estelle) Scissor. (She gets the scissors from the coffee table and hands them to George with the point facing him) Don't hand them to me with the point facing out!
You're sorry?!
(Stern, angered) I hope so. (Takes the scissors)

Alright! Please, please! I cannot have this constant bickering!.. Stress is very damaging to the epidermis! Now, I have an important photo session in the morning - my hands have got to be in tip-top shape, so please - keep the television down, and the conversation to a minimum.
(Definite) I'll take it in my room. (Walks off)
Who was he?
(Hands still out, even though they've stopped looking at them) What happened to him?
You mean, uh..?
(Makes a gesture saying he understands. The man nods) But how.. uh..?
(Smiling to himself) You don't have to worry about me. (Nodding, gloating) I won a contest.
Like that?
That's it?
(Modest) Oh, thank you very much. (Chuckles)

(Quick, excited talking) Hey, hey! You can't believe this. Look at this check! (Hands it to Jerry) They told me I had the most beautiful hands they'd ever seen in their lives - except for this McKigney guy - this great looking girl gave me her phone number.. I got it! I got it all! I'm busting. Jerry, I'm busting!
Alright. (Holds them up)

(Turning back to Jerry, he takes the check back. He just now notices the shirt Jerry's wearing, and snickers, pointing) Nice shirt.. (Laughs, Jerry shrugs) What is this? Is this what you wore on the show?
What, have you completely lost your mind?

Who's dressing you? (Laughs) You look like a complete idiot! You know, I wouldn't wipe my- (Unable to take anymore, Leslie gets up and shoves George violently. His hands go straight for the hot iron sitting on the dressing room table. George screams out in agony) AAHHHH!!!!! (his voice is heard outside the building, on the street, and in the park were a bunch of pigeons are scared by the yelling)
Ow! Hot! Hot!
(Reflecting on his life gone wrong) This McKigney guy had a few good years.. (To Kramer, bitter) How could you forget to turn off an iron?
My whole life is ruined because of the (Mocking, bitter tone) "puffy shirt".
Okay, well, he had this idea of a pizza place where you make your own pie! (Laughs)
What's that?
Yep. Yeah..
(Interested) Oh?
Oh, a puffy shirt.
Uh, o... (Remembers something they could talk about) Jerry's going to be on the "Today" show on Friday.
Yep.. yep. Um, he's promoting a (pauses) benefit for Goodwill, you know, they, uh, they clothe the (clears her throat) poor, and the homeless..
And the indigent, yeah.. I, I do volunteer work for them. I-I set the whole thing up, and I got Jerry to do it.
Ohh, yeah. Yeah.. yep.
Yep.
Mmm
Why don't you want to take a civil service test?
Hi, Kramer. Guess what - I just saw Bryant Gumbel, he said he might help out at the benefit!
(Between laughs) What is that?!
(To Jerry) Why're you wearing that now?
When did she, (Snickers) when did she ask you this?
I didn't hear anything.
(Just now making the matter serious) Well, you can't wear that on the show.

(Turning around to Kramer) Wha- What? No. (Back to Jerry) Jerry, you are promoting a benefit to CLOTHE homeless people. You can't come out dressed like that! You're all puffed up!.. You look like the Count of Monte Cristo!
(Arguing) Yeah, but you're supposed to be a compassionate person! That cares about poor people! You look like you're gonna.. swing in on a chandelier!
Hey, I've never noticed your hands before. Let me see.
(Obviously not impressed, dull) Yeah, real nice.
You ready?
(Sincere) I'm sorry.
(Reflecting) Well, it got me fired from the benefit committee.
Alright. I'm ready. (To George) You know, I still don't understand - why do you want to move back in with your parents?
Well, move in here.
Why doesn't he just move in here?
You can move in with me, if you want.
Hello, Mrs. Costanza.
Well, I gotta bring in more stuff. (Heads for the door)
Yeah. (Exits)
Uhh.. no thanks. (Goes back out the door)
(Enters with a box) Alright, that's it. Anything else?
Oh, I gotta go move the car. Alright (Leaves)
Yeah, well, that was a good one.
You know that, uh, Leslie (Points to her) is in the clothing business? She's a designer.

In fact, she's come up with a new one that is going to be the big new look in men's fashion.. It's a, a puffy shirt. (Leslie mumbles to Kramer) Well, yeah, it - it's all puffy. Like the pirates used to wear.
Yeah, see, I think people want to look like pirates. You know, it's the right time for it.. to be all puffy, and devil-may-care..
(Still laughing) That's true.. (Gets up) I'll be right back. (Walks off laughing. Jerry and Elaine are left with the low-talker. A moment passes)
Hey. (He's carrying a suit cover. He hangs it on Jerry's coat hooks)
Hey, George! (Holds out his hand. George shakes it - a hand buzzer goes off. George starts freaking out. Kramer laughs)
What?!
(Laughing) But, it's only a toy!
A hand model?
(To George) Really? Let me see your hands.
Let's see.. (studies them) oh, those are nice. You know, I've never noticed this before? They're smooth.. creamy.. delicate, yet (Turns to Jerry) masculine.
Yeah..

You're not going to believe what happening with Leslie. You know, ever since you agreed to wear the puffy shirt on the Today show, she's been getting all these orders from boutiques and department stores..
Agreed to wear the puffy shirt. (Starts unzipping the suit cover)
When you said that you'd agree to wear the puffy shirt on the Today show. (Takes the ridiculous puffy shirt out of the cover)
Yea.
Yeah, yeah.
When we went to dinner the other night.
What were you talking about when I went to the bathroom?
(makes his pop sound) There you go.
Yes, yes! You said it!
(Takes it off the hook, and starts walking toward Jerry with it. He backs defensively backs away from it) Well, she asked you.
Well, you gotta wear it now! All those stores are stocking it based on the condition that you're gonna wear this on the TV show! The factory in New Jersey is already makin' em.
Yes, yes. This pirate trend that she's come up with, Jerry, this-this is gonna be the new look for the 90's. You're gonna be the first pirate!
Yeah, come in.
Giddy-Up. (Stagehand leaves) Jerry! Five minutes!

Now that's a great looking shirt! (Gets up, admiring the shirt) Aye Captain! (Growls like a pirate) Yeah! I'm glad I ironed it. It's perfect. (Walks around Jerry, inspecting the shirt) Look at it! It's fantastic!
(Reassuring) Hey, this look's better than anything you own. You know, in two months time, everybody's gonna be wearing the (imitates a pirate) pirate look!
Yeah.
Great.
It's the puffy shirt. Look at it, eh? Whatd'ya think? Is it cool or what?
(To Elaine, muffled, low, and threatening) Elaine, you want to stop?
(Faint, trying to shut George up) Hey..
Well, I was excited because Jerry was putting on the puffy shirt.
You know all those stores canceled out on her? She's finished. (Concluding) We're (Leslie and him) finished.
(Showing pure irony) I just can't be with someone who's life is in complete disarray.
They gave them all to Goodwill.
No. You?
Yeah.
Hey.
You got me the air conditioner?
Beautiful!
Is it a good one?
Commando 8?
All right.
Yeah.
So you're tunneling to the center of the Earth? (Elaine laughs silently)
He was running from a bee. (Elaine laughs)
There's a lot of change down there.
We're behind you, Aquaboy. Godspeed!
Hey, he just got me thirty percent off on an air conditioner.
(bored) Come on, George. Pick a face and go with it.
(While looking at posters of women wearing glasses) I think these women would be pretty good looking if they weren't wearing glasses.
Are you okay? Did he bite ya?
Oh I'm gonna take you over to the emergency room.
(To George:) Hey, any luck? Did you catch 'em?
All right, I'm gonna take Elaine over to the hospital.
What's the matter?
What is it?
Yeah, yeah, in a second, in a second. (And to George:) What do you mean you can't tell me?
I'm asking!
Yeah, yeah, take care of it. (Jerry throws her some toilet paper) Come on, George, what is it?
What?
Amy and Jeffrey?
Are you sure?
But you can't see, there's no lenses in those frames.
We're gonna have to talk about this later. (Elaine holds the door open for Jerry while holding her leg) Thank you. Taxi!
Why not? They could have met. She loves the park, he works for the Parks Department.
But he was squinting.

Are you kidding? I've seen 'em squint. He can squint his way down to like twenty, thirty vision. Once we were driving down from the Catskills and he lost his glasses. He squinted his way from Wortsborough down to the Tappan Zee Bridge! He was spotting raccoons, on the road!
Nah, look at this. Cable's out.

No, no, no. No trouble at all, it's a principal the thing. (Jerry picks up the phone and dials the number) I like them to know that I know what's going on. That they're not... getting away with anything. Oh, I'm on hold. So, what did you do yesterday?
Yeah, you remember yesterday? Beautiful day... good day to be... out.
(laughing) Oh you must have done something.
Didn't go out of the house? Didn't take a walk... on Columbus Avenue?
Well, your day's getting more interesting already. (Jerry shows the phone) Ah, see, told me they'd be back in a minute and THEY lied.
No you can't. (hangs up the phone) Now let's cut the ball, sister! You think I don't know about you swapping spit with somebody yesterday on Columbus Avenue?
Look, my friend saw you.
You tell me.
There isn't?
Oh... all right... wanna get some pizza?
Why?
No, no, there's no side!
No, no, no ugly side.
Why?
Uuh, so we can still go out on Friday though?
It's coming! It's a Commando 8! 12.000 BTU's! It's gonna be like a meat locker in here.
I was an idiot for listening to you!
Ooh, everything was going so well. She hadn't seen any flaws in me. Now she sees a side.
A bad side, an ugly side.
So what? I wasn't planning on showing that side for another six months. Now you make me throw off the whole learning curve.
Ah, he'd just deny it.
Amy said nothing happened.
Yeah, but you're blind as a bat!
They were mailboxes, you idiot. I didn't have the heart to tell you.
(Stunned:) No, keep it. (Elaine enters the apartment) Hey what happened to you? You buzzed five minutes ago.
A little white dog?
Snowball? You were afraid of Snowball?
He's like a squirrel.
You know, you should just go back to the optical store and ask Dwayne if he knows the name of the owner of the dog.
Hey, Kramer, Elaine's afraid of Snowball!
I don't know what to believe! You're eating unions, you're spotting dimes, I don't know what the hell is going on.

Hey wait a second, wait a second. I'm going over to Jeffrey's apartment tomorrow night to pick up these Paul Simon tickets. I'm gonna surprise Amy. All I gotta do is bring her with me. And then when Jeffrey opens the door, it's Howdy Doody time.
I don't know what to tell you, Elton.
(To George:) Who picked these out?
They're ladies' glasses! You know all you need is that little chain around your neck so you can wear 'em while you're playing Canasta.
Hey, hey.
Take it to the window.
Just in time for Amy.
Rabies.
Hey, hey, what is this? What's going on here?
Oh he'll be home, it's Friday night. That's the big night on the Nature Channel.
He does look like a horse.
Hey, shall we spit on him?
Oh, you'll find out.
Well, I'm very mysterious by nature. (Jerry knocks on the door) A lot of women find that attractive.
Oh?
Uncle Leo?!
This is Amy.
Unlce Leo, what are you doing here?
Ooh! Very convenient.
Oh really?
Uncle Leo! Did he leave any tickets here for me?
Thank you.
To the Paul Simon concert in the park!
That's right, lady!
I thought you'd like that.
Now you know. That, and that alone, is the reason.
Thank you.
(To Amy:) Aha! So it's true! You were making out with him!
Oh very convincing, but it's not gonna work this time.
Oh... oh... wanna get some pizza?
I still don't know how you spotted that dime. I think you planted it. Plus I had to pay that vet bill for the stupid dog. I don't know how that guy got my name.
I gotta get out of this city.
I'm at the health club and while I'm in the pool, some guy walks off with my glasses. Who steals prescription glasses?
I broke 'em playing basketball.
Now if I wanna see anything I gotta wear these.
When I find that guy, this much I vow: those glasses will be returned to their rightful owner.
What kind of a sick, demented person wants another person's glasses?
Yeah, come on.
Really?
Wow. Uh, what do I have to do?
That's it?
What about these?
Well, it's a tough decision. I have to wear these every day. I'm deciding on a new face.
Yes, they are bold. Jerry, what do you think?
Can you believe that guy?
He just walked away! And once again I'm standing here like a little man. Well not this time! (George leaves the store and follows the dog owner) You! Dog man!
Uuh, no, no.
(In a really strange way) Good, good, do that.
Oh, no, nothing.
I can't tell you.
I can't tell you, don't ask.
I saw Amy making out with your cousin Jeffrey.
They were right outside!
Yes!
Yes, positive.
I know! I was squinting.
(To the store owner:) Excuse me, what do you think of these?
Yes, it is exciting! All right, this is gonna be my new face.
Yeah. (George hands over the prescription) Kramer...
Kramer...
You do know Kramer?
Well, I'm mentioning his name.
Because... you know...
Hey, I saw what I saw.
What side?
Ooh, so what?
Why don't you just ask Jeffrey?
There must be some way to find out.
What, you're gonna take her word over mine? I'm your best friend!
I was squinting! Remember that drive from Wortsborough? (snapping his fingers) I was spotting those raccoons.
(noticing something) Hey look, a dime.
Heh, Mercury head. You mind?
Did you get the shot?
You got bit by a strange dog and you didn't get a rabies shot?
Pardon me, I went to see your friend Dwayne... there was no discount.
That's right, no discount!
Yes, I mentioned your name.
Pbbbs, Bubkis!
All right, let me just... I'm gonna grap an apple.
Yes it is.
I saw them making out, you can believe it.
(crying from the onion) You'll see I'm right.
Elaine, don't interrupt, they're discounting something.
I did!
Well Elaine was supposed to help me.
That's it? You don't have to screw it in or anything?
Oh yeah, when are you gonna execute that plan?
Madam? What are you calling me madam for?
He sold me ladies' glasses!
Ah, Oh boy.
Oh uuh, sure, why not. (the blind man hangs on to George's arm) Hey, that's the guy.
The guy that stole my glasses. This time I got 'em! (George follows the man onto the street, dragging the blind man with him) Would you pick it up a little?
He's getting on a bus, damn! (To the blind man:) Those are nice glasses.
Is that right?
Dwayne, my friend and I would like to exchange frames. Could you put his lenses in my frames and mine in his?
And I'd like a discount.
Listen, you're lucking I'm not asking for a whole refund. (trying to speak quietly) You gave me ladies' frames!
Yeah, well, she's trying to track you down.
No, that's Jerry.
Yeah, 5A!
Boy, these really do pinch the nose.
Oh my God it is them.
Yeah. Hmm. Boy these really do pinch. I tell you, if I ever find the son of a bitch that stole my glasses...
Do you ever spit on anybody from here?
No. Do you ever think about it?
Me too.
What air conditioner?
I thought you hated air conditioning. You've never had an air conditioner.
Oooh, you're getting an air conditioner for Amy. (In a wining voice:) Amy doesn't like the temperature up here. She's a little hoooot.
You don't have an old pair?
George, those are prescription goggles? What is there to see in a health club pool?
Yeah, especially those frames.
They look good. I liked the other one too. I've liked about five of them.
Now those look good, they're very bold.
Hi there, little doggy. (to owner:) Do you mind if I pet your dog?
Hey little doggy. (Elaine pets the dog and he bites her) Aaah!
I'm okay, it's just a nip.
My leg looks pretty bad.
Okay.
(pulling on Jerry's pants from the ground) Jerry, can we go?
Jerry, my leg.
Okay, listen, Jerry, you just catch up with me okay? You can just follow the trail of blood.
Oh, come on. Cousin Jeffrey? It's not possible!
Jerry, that is so ridiculous. But, George didn't even have his glasses on!
So what? Squinting doesn't make that much of a difference.
Okay? That's it? I don't need a shot?
No, no, no. I know I wasn't shot. Do I need a shot?
There was a dog in front of the building and it spooked me. I couldn't come in until he left.
Yeah.
I'm afraid of dogs now.
Well he frightened me.
No. He said I didn't need a shot.
What, you think I should have?
All right, that's a good idea. I'm gonna do that.
You know, George, that's an onion.
He couldn't tell an apple from an union and he's your eye witness?
Uhm excuse me... uh... a man came in here...
Can I just have the name...
(While reading a book:) Oh oh, listen to this, this is not good, listen to these symptoms for rabies: anxiety, irritability. I got those, I'm irritable!
Hey! I got bit by a dog! I had to go to the hospital! I was bleeding to death! I can't solve every little problem you have!
I'm sorry... sorry.
I've got such a headache. Oh, that's another symptom!

ca.

ah.

Cut it.
Cut it.

Ow. My eye, my eye.

Oh forget it, I hate those. Everytime I take one, the driver will *not* stop talking to me. No matter how disinterested I seem he just keeps yakking away. Blah, blah, blah, blah, blah. Why does everything always have to have a social componant? Now a stage coach, that would have been a good situation for me. Cause I'm in the coach, and the driver is way up there on the stage.
Yea, I guess that could work.
Pardon me?
Yeah.

No. When I shoo squirrels away, I always say "get out of here". I never ever throw things at them and try to injure them like other people.
Yeah, and when I see freaks in the street I never, ever stare at them. Yet, I'm careful not to look away, see, because I want to make the freaks feel comfortable.
Yeah, and I don't poof up my hair when I got to a movie so people behind me can see. I've got to make it up to this guy or I won't be able to live with myself. What can I do?
Really?
Oh great, thanks Kramer.
Yeah I think he's right. I've never seen a ball man.

Can't hear a thing.

Yeah, yeah me too. Yeah he was at the snack bar eating a hot fudge sundae. He had it all over his face. He was wearing that chocolate on his face like a beard and they got in there real nice and tight. And he's... (Imitates scooping up ice cream. Elaine and Jerry laugh)

-ca.

"Why don't you stick around and we can sleep together."

Hi.

They're doing an incredible business.

(answering the buzzer) Yeah?

Kramer!
Me?

I've gained eight.
How did I gain eight?

It was an accident. I'm going to talk to him.
How's it doing?

Oh.

Because she's like the jury. She's going to be sequestered.
Well, I think the whole thing stinks.
That's enough.
With the smelling.

Hey.
No, I believe he can.
Hi!

That's true. But it was an accident. And I haven't done it since. And I would never do it again. And if you continue cursing, you'll never become a comedian like me when you grow up. (phone rings) Excuse me one second.
(quickly moves over toward Matthew) What the *beep*(fuck) are you doing? You little piece of *beep*(shit)!
(surprised) He said that?

Name tags?
Oh, I see. So you can go, "Hey, you know who I saw wilding today? Herb!"

Well, we've got to do something. (grabs his phone) I'm calling Giuliani's headquarters.
The old yogurt was so much better. Oh, this is terrible.
I can't eat this.

Fantastic!
Good.

(offers his) Oh, you want to taste mine.

Hey
Oh, don't tell me. Lloyd?

Yeah, yeah. Big advisor.

Yes.
Uh-huh.
Hmm. Really? Nothing?
Well, it's kind of a mystery, isn't it?

Now, see here, doctor.
Fine. (hits his arm on the desk) Ow!
Name tags! Name tags! What kind of an idiot thinks anybody would be interested in an idea like that.
I banged it on the desk in the doctor's office. An (worriedly rubbing his arm) aaaa . . .
Phew!
Hmm!

Hi!
Hi!
Nice to meet you, too!
(excited about Lloyd) Aaah. Boy, he is really cute!
(on the buzzer) Buzz me.
Hey!
Oh, I was having lunch, and I bit down on the fork.
What?
(quietly) What?
Where's your bathroom scale? (Jerry looks at her like 'where do you think?' Elaine and Jerry both go into the bathroom) Oh my god, I've gained seven pounds.

I don't get it. I, I've been doing the same exercises. I haven't been eating anything different.
I don't eat Oreos.
Jerry, there's got to be a way to find that out.
AH! I've got it.
I'll call the Food and Drug Administration.
Uh-huh. Okay, well, we're coming down. All right. (hangs up the phone) Okay. I got a place that can analyze it. It's in Brooklyn. We have to drive there.
Yeah, it's forty-five bucks.
Hm-hmm.
I want a small, plain vanilla in a cup to go. That's non-fat, right?
'Cause I'm on a special diet, and the doctor said I can't have any fat.
Hurry, Jerry! Hurry!
Not so good.
Um, hi! Hi. I called earlier about getting the yogurt tested.
Uh, does it matter if it's melted?
That's okay.
Okay, I'm done.
It smells. Smells bad. Smells really bad.
What?
Hey!
So, guess who called me.
We're going out tomorrow night.
I can't say that.
What if I like him? I'm going to start out lying to this guy?
No. But what if we get married or something? We'll always have that between us.
You never know.
All right, well, then what if we become a couple, George? Every time we see you you're going to be walking around going like this? (moving her arm) Even you can't keep that up.

He tells him which soap to use.

Well, as far as I know, he bumped his arm into a door and it's kind of got this in(pauses)voluntarily movement. Some sort of a (clears her throat) spasm. So, anyway, you're a..you're a big advisor to Dinkins, huh?
Wow! You know what I would do if I was running for mayor. One of my campaign themes would be that everybody should wear name tags all the time to make the city friendlier.

Yaow.

The old-fashioned barber shop is unfortunately becoming a thing of the past, now what went wrong? Well first of all there's a twenty thousand dollar chair to make a three dollar tip. Yeah, I see what you mean. I forgot who I was dealing with here.
So what did you do there all day?
So it's a nice place to work?
What about your boss? The guys you interviewed you?
Hi.
I got a haircut.
Oh there's nothing to see.
Forget it.
All right.

Well I'll tell you this, you can forget about me going to that bachelor auction.
Hey
Yeah, but how am I...
Oh. thank you.
Well actually Enzo hasn't said that to me in a while.
That's nice of you to say.
In the one minute he worked on me I could tell he was really good.
Yeah.
Enzo picked up one of my hairs off the floor.
I think he knew.
Who do you know? He knows my hair.
Okay, okay.
He didn't get to finish it. His uncle came in. We almost got caught.
Take the K-man.
How do you know?
Who is it?
All right, go in the bedroom. Open the window. You can go out the fire escape.
What do you want?
What's wrong with yours?
You can't unclog it?
Did you ask Kramer?
Number one?
All right. Flush twice.
All right?
All right, I'll see you later.
I'm watching Edward Scissorhands.
Yeah all right.
You want something to drink?
If you want to watch, sit down. You're making me nervous. I tell you this Scissorhands is a hell of a barber.
I don't get this Scissorhands. What, is he supposed to be like a super hero, like Green Lantern or somebody? What's with this guy? (Gino looks at him annoyed) Just asking.
Who is it?
Oh my god, he knows. (Jerry and Gino scrambling) Go. (yelling to the door) One second.
No I wasn't there. (enters and slams the door)
Sample? (under his breath) Newman. Uh, I was there but I was just dropping off a book.

I enjoy understanding.
I want you to have this job. Of course...
That's it.
He never finished the sentence. He got a call, that was the end of the interview.
Maybe he was going to say "Of course I have to check with my associates."
All right.
Because he made a big deal about how I understand everything immediately. That's what impressed him.
And if I don't call...
Rest stop supply.
Hey
I had a job interview.
Good. Of course...
He massacred you.
You look like you're five years old.
You've got to start seeing someone else. Get out of this relationship.
Well, you gotta do it.
So I still haven't heard about that job.
I have an idea.
I show up.
I show up. I pretend I have the job. The guy's on vacation. If I have the job, it's fine. If I don't have the job, by the time he comes back, I'm ensconced.
What's the worst thing that could happen?
Yeah, so?
(to various people as he walks in) Good morning. Good morning. Good morning. Hi nice to see you. How are you. Good morning. (to the secretary) Good morning.
The name's George Constanza. I'm starting work here today. I was wondering if you could tell me where my office is.
Thanks Mike. Nice to be aboard.
Oh, well, he was probably just getting anxious to start his vacation.
Oh leave Jack alone. Jack's got enough problems. I'll just take the small office.
Yes. I like to feel cozy. I have a very small apartment. I like to feel tucked in, nestled in. Love to be nestled.
Yes, yes of course. The Pensky file. Ho ho, can't wait to sink my teeth into that. Wow that Pensky. Well we'll straighten him out.
They gave me the Pensky file.
You know I'm enjoying it very much. I think my coworkers are really taking to me.
(continuing) I feel like a family. In fact, yesterday was Grace's birthday. She's such a sweet woman so, we had a little party, with cake and champagne. I made a toast.
He'll be back on Monday.
You know Elaine, I'd do it but I'm working that day.
Mr. Pensky? Of the Pensky file?
Mr. Pensky. I was just working on your file. I was transferring the contents of the file into this flexible accordion-style folder.
He's on vacation.
Well you know in college they used to call me the little bulldog.

Not now Florice.
I am aware. I am aware.

You are?

Ah, here it is.

Well bear in mind that I am in the smaller office.
You are aware that Pensky is interested in me.
(chuckles) Really? Well, we'll just see about that. Ta-ta, Tut-tle.
Obviously.
JERRY & ELAINE: Yeah?
"I want you to have this job, of course the Board of Directors is under indictment and will be serving time."
Why don't you go ahead and call him?
Good for you.

Come on.
(still laughing, tears in her eyes) I'm sorry. I'm so sorry.

Can he fix it?

You think?

Oh, Kramer. Okay uh, why don't we start the bidding. Do I hear, um, five bucks?
Yeah, yeah, yeah.
Hey.
Haircut.
I'm very happy with this.
Oh course. I wouldn't let that other butcher cut my hair.
The uncle Enzo. That's the guy Jerry uses.
You can get a good one today. It's Enzo's day off. Gino's there all by himself.
What bachelor auction?
And you didn't ask me to do it? I could raise enough money to cure polio.
Polio?
What are you all dressed up for?

No way my Gino did that. It's an Enzo.

His feelings? You can't continue seeing him. You're destroying yourself.
I'm not going to let you. If you don't call him I will.
I'm going to call Gino, you're going to see him, and we're going to get that haircut fixed up.
All right, geez. You're crazy.
It the worst haircut Jerry's ever had. You gotta fix it.
Yeah yeah yeah.
I'd like to have shoehorn hands.
Hey.
Okay listen to me. I talked to Gino, he's going to fix the haircut.
No buts. His apartment tonight, Eight o'clock.
I don't know.
Yeah. Slow, gentle, attentive.
I told you he could do it.
Yeah, so?
No. He doesn't know.
Listen you're just imagining things. He doesn't know a thing. Now come on. Pull yourself together.
What are you kidding? Look at him. He's grotesque.
Do I think? He's repugnant.
Whatever it takes.
Equivalency.
(on the phone in Jerry's apartment) So when are you gonna be able to go out?

If there's a serial killer lose in your neighborhood, it seems like the safest thing is to be the neighbor. They never kill the neighbor. The neighbor always survives to do the interview afterwards. Right? "Oh, he was kind of quiet." I love these neighbors. They're never disturbed by the sounds of murdering, just stereo. Chain saws, people screaming, fine. Just keep the music down. And all these women who always fall in love with the serial killer. They write to him in prison. Here's a woman that's hard to disappoint. I guess she's only upset when she finds out he's stopped killing people and she goes: "You know sometimes I feel like I don't even know who you are anymore".
No eight years isn't such a long streak.
No I haven't vomited in thirteen years.
Not since June 29, 1980.
Yes, because my previous vomit was also June 29th... 1972. That's why during the '80 vomit, I was yelling to George: "Can you believe it? I'm vomiting on June 29th again."
No Elaine he's normal. Your boyfriend is a normal guy. He just happens to have the same name as one of the worst serial killers in the history of New-York.
But you like your Joel Rifkin.
Ask him to change it.
Why not?
If someone asked me nicely. I'm Claude Seinfeld.
Yeah. Eighteen strangles.
Hey did you hear that George got back with Karen?
Risotto. (we see a flashback from The Mango where Karen tells George that she feels full after a Risotto, as opposed to when she has sex with him)
Yeah. He's really got a good thing with her. In fact I'm doubling with them tonight.
George likes them, he feels it's a good personality showcase. He likes a date to see him with a friend so she can get a window into his nondate personality.
He feels he's funnier, more relaxed.
Jody the masseuse.
No! How many times do I have to go out with her before I get a massage?
Yeah I know... She just wants to have sex.
So it's like going to Idhao and eating carrots. I like carrots, but I'm in Idhao, I want a potato.
(to Jody) My neck is killing me. Right in this spot. Very tender over here.
(touching the back of his neck) It's like somebody's pulling on wires back here.
Yeah. Let's go.
Yeah. Good seeing you again Karen.
I strained my neck last night.
I tried brushing my teeth by holding the brush and moving my head from side to side. It didn't work.
No deal. Why?
Oh well, he was just showcasing his nondate pesonality.
Yeah. Sometimes he really makes me tense (he takes Jody's hand and put it on his shoulder)
Yeah, he's disgusting. (putting her hand back on his shoulder. She unconsciously starts to massage a little while watching TV)
Yeah, me either. (he takes her other hand and put it on his other shoulder)
Yeah, he's a bad seed.
What are you doing?
Yeah. (disappointed)
No. The sex was fabulous.
I want the massage!
I tried putting her hands there (on his neck) but she pulls it away immediately, she's not into it.
I guess 'cause it's her job. It's very frustrating.
Yeah.
Yeah.
She had a good time.
Pretty much.
What?
Yeah (a so-so yeah as he takes a sip of coffee)
I was blowing on the coffee.
Look it's not like you're gonna be spending a lot of time with her.
No.
Yes.
Yes.
"I don't like him."
Not everybody likes everybody!
You were very nice!
It has nothing to do with her sister.
Oh no. That was the dry heaves.
Jodi.
What are you doing here?
Kramer! (tries to hide he's upset and jealous)
I'll see you tonight. (he's opening his door apartment as Kramer comes out of his in a bathrobe)
Who told you to get a massage from her. I haven't gotten a massage from her yet!
So you had a good time.
Enjoyed yourself.
All right now you listen and you listen good! (he grabs Kramer's legs and throws him down the couch)
The massages are out!
Ahh!!! They're out!
Because if I can't get one, you're not getting one.
I'm sorry, Kramer. (he goes back to the kitchen)
Don't you ever talk about her like that!
That's final!!!
What's the matter with you?
You just had one yesterday. What do you need another one for?
Oh please.
Well, did you get the ball?
Well, I never even caught a foul ball at a baseball game.
Why don't you get somebody else?
Well, that's it! Tonight's the night. I'm getting one. No "if and's or but's".
(whining like Kramer) Ask Newman.
Hi.
Ah, no problem. That's fine.
That's new age music. Sounds of the forest. I find it soothing. Hey, look at this! What do you know? A massage table! This is great! (he starts to install the table)
Just checking it out. Look at how this thing is made. Can I tell you something? That's a hell of a piece of equipment.
No, nonsense. This one's fine. (as he sits on the table)

Go? Why go anywhere? (as he places his hand over hers. She starts to massage his shoulders a little) Ahh, that feels good. Yeah. That's, uh... That's good. (he tries to go further. He grabs her hands over his shoulders and he lies down on the table on his chest) Yeah, that's nice. That's very nice.
Why, what's wrong? (he grabs her hands and force her to keep them on his shoulders)
No. Yes you can. (he hangs on)
Come on! I know it's something you wanna do! (she pulls harder and he falls right off the table)
What do you mean, no?
Look, who are you kidding? You come up to my apartment with your table and your little oils, and I'm not supposed to expect anything? You're a massage teaser.
Fine. Go.
What for?
You need to talk?
George, anything you have to say to her, you can say in front of me.
What?
I can see that.
Don't worry. (she leaves)
You're a lucky guy.
George. I wouldn't push for the massage. (George nods)

The swedish are very big massagers. You know? They like the swedish meatballs, swedish massage. They like having meat in their hands these people, for some reason. But it's weird because they have the highest suicide rate, they're rubbing each other's necks all the time for a neutral country they seem kinda tense. I don't really like the idea of getting a professional massage. I don't want people touching me that don't know me and don't want to have sex with me. You know what are you bothering me for? You get me all loosened up, juices flowing, and then that's it ok, you're done. It's like having chocolate rubbed all over your face, you know you wanna go "Excuse me, I think you missed a spot."

(George is telling a story. Karen is laughing and she seems to be the only one to find him funny) So I go into this clothing store and the saleswoman is wearing this (whistling) low cut thing. (to Jody) You're listening to this?
Well nothing. I didn't actually say that. (Karen is still laughing)
Sweetheart, I was exaggerating.
You know it's like you never see a really attractive woman getting a traffic ticket.
Well I've never met your sister but obviously these are not hard-and-fast rules. (to the waitress) Darling, the tea is getting a little cold sweetheart.
Jody let's do this agian real soon (he tends his arms for a hug but she avoids him)
So, what do you think?
Jody's nice.
You think she liked me? She seemed to like me.
I was personable. Don't you think I was personable?
I tought I picked up a little something. I'm very good at this. Did you pick up anything?
The second time I sent the noodles back, I tought she made a face...
I tought I saw a face.

He he he he

So?

We all got along. Everyone seemed very pleasant.

Is that it?
Did she say anything about, uh...

You just hesitated.

So she doesn't like me?

What were her exact--
Uh-Huh (gulp) Why didn't she like me?
I tried to be nice. I wasn't nice?
I bent over backwards for that woman! Is it that thing I said about her sister?
I don't even know her sister but believe me, if she's getting traffic tickets, she's not that good-looking! Woah
You vomited in 1987.
Ha! Ha! Hey! (moving his arms like: it's so great to be all here)
Here. Let me take your tabe downstairs for you.
Please give it to me. I love to help people. This is what I do. Come on. I'm going this way. (he takes the table from Jodi's hands and she has no choice but to follow him)

No one hails a cab like me. My hailing technique is unmatched. I get the wrist going from side to side and boom! Cabs are crashing into themselves to just pick me up. (a cab stops) All right, here we go. Let me get door. Feminists aside, I know women like the door holding. Here we are all righty. O.K. Jodi let's get together again real soon and say hello to your sister for me.

Whatever. Believe me, if I wasn't involved right now, I wouldn't mind being set up. Something tells me she's a knockout. (we see, from the camera inside the cab, George's hand waving as the cab drives away)
So I lugged that table. That big heavy massage table all the way down to the cab! You ever seen one of those things?
No, I don't know. Maybe you haven't. You know, not everybody's seen a massage table.
Anyway, I don't even get a thank you. I don't get it!
I wanna know what I did to this woman.
No, No! She's going out with a friend of mine. It's only courteous that we should try and like each other.
Yes! Yes! Everybody has to like me. I must be liked!

You know what? I should really go talk to her. Nothing confrontational. Just two adults sitting down trying to clear the air. You know, I just know if I could spend some time alone with her. I've got to. (he grabs his jacket) I've got to.
I think I can still catch her.
What? What are you talking about.
I know. I know.
(he thinks a little about it... and as he puts his hand on his knee and gets up) I'm sorry Karen. I know I care for you, but I just can't stand when someone doesn't like me. (he opens the door)
That I'm used to. (he leaves)
Jerry, could you excuse us for a few minutes, please?
We need to talk.
Look it's no secret what's going on between us. (to Jerry) She doesn't like me. Now Jerry if you don't mind.
(he makes a sign to Jodi to wait and turns to Jerry) Jerry... This woman hates me so much. I'm starting to like her.
She just dislikes me so much... It's irresistable.
A woman that hates me this much comes along once in a lifetime.
I got to go after her.
JODI! (he starts running after her)
It isn't?
Get out!
You remember the date?
Boy, you know when Joel told me he hadn't thrown up in eight years, I was wondering if he was normal.
Yeah... (2 co-workers enter Elaine's office) Oh Jer, I gotta go. I gotta go. (she hangs up)
Oh, yeah?
Joel...
Uh... (clears her throat) Rifkin.
Yeah. It's just a coincidence obviously.
Very funny. That's very funny.
All right. Well that's enough of that. That's enough.

(she's upset, gets up and yells) OK look this is my boyfriend we're talking about OK? And he's a gentlemen, he's good looking, he's a good shaver and he hasn't thrown up in eigth years so just shut up about him! Shut up!
The whole city is talking about this monster Joel Rifkin, and I am dating a Joel Rifkin.
Yeah. I just wish he has a different name.
You can't ask a person to change their name.
Would you change yours?
Hey, how many people did Rifkin strangle? Eighteen?
You know Joel and I have an extra ticket to the Giants game.
O.K. I'll leave the ticket for you at will call.
You think I should have asked George?
Karen?
Oh! The Risotto broad.
I tought you didn't like double dates.
I've looked through that window and screamed at him to shut the blinds.
And you're taking...
Hey, did you get a massage yet?
Jerry, she gives massages all day. She doesn't wanna to give them on dates.
So what?
(as he touches her) Uhh! What are you doing?
Oh. Huh. Of course. Massaging.
Yeah, yeah. You know what? There are a lot of players named Deon these days. What a cool name, Deon. If I were gonna change my name, I'd go with Deon.
Well as a woman, it makes no sense. But, I mean, let's say I was you. And I decided I was gonna change my name for no real reasons whatsoever-- Deon Rifkin. Wow! That is so cool.

Well maybe you're not the Dion type. O.K. then let's see, let's see, what do we got? (looking at the magazine, she starts to gasp and loses it) Oh! Oh oh oh! O.J.! O.J. Rifkin! You don't even use a name, it's just initials. Oh please please please change your name to O.J.! Please, it would be so great!
Oh, you have photos in your wallet?
No, it's normal. You're very normal. You're totally normal. Who's this?
Oh yeah. I see the resemblance.
Yeah, there is, right here you see--
(pause) Oh. That's nice.
(to the person in front of her) He's not the murderer.
Of course I support your decision to change your name.
Well, listen, I just want you to know that I was more than willing to stick it out with Joel Rifkin.
(she fakes a strangling) RRR...
Yeah. Yeah. 10 names.
O.K. And if somebody objects, you can just veto it.
O.K. You start. What's your first choice?
(right away) No. Second choice.
I have never met a normal guy named Stuart.
(repeating to hear how it sounds) Todd. (pause) No. Veto.
Great...
I gotta tell ya, I have a bad association with the name Alex.

Yeah, in college I sat next to an Alex in art history. And he was always drinking coffee and after every sip he would go: "Ahh". I mean every two seconds: "Ahh". And he would take like 40 sips and after everyone: "Ahh". I had to drop the class.
What is wrong with Ned?
Ellis.
Ellis and Alex aren't even close.
Ohh, what is the point?
O.K. O.K. Remy.
Oh, Stuart's a lot better! (talking like a baby) Little Stuart Rifkin likes to go shopping with his mother.

You know why Rifkin was a serial killer? Because he was adopted. (saying it as he's taking a lot of paper towels from Jerry's roll; Elaine and Jerry are confused at Kramer's statement) Just like Son of Sam was adopted. So apparently adoption leads to serial killing. (Kramer leaves and we don't know why he needed so much paper towels)
I'll go.
Yeah! Ooh! (leaves again)
Hey! I am looser than creamed corn!
You don't know what you're missing buddy.

(Kramer is talking much more slowly and smoother than usual) First she sets the mood perfectly with this new age music played over ocean sounds. Then she lays you out on this table, and she proceeds to rub oil over your entire body. And she rubs long... and deep... Jerry, she rubs with love. (Jerry is obviously cutting much harder than the cheese needs it as he listens to Kramer) Every muscles she touches just... (long pause) ooo-zz-es. Beneath those silky, soft fingers, you can scarcely contain yourself, buddy. (Jerry slams down the knife and goes to the couch)
Oh... yeah...
Very... much...
What! (Kramer is back to his usual way of speaking)
Wha--
Why?!
Wait a minute! Wait a minute! I need my massages! Can't you see I'm burned out!
Why? Why? Look, I paid for her. (Jerry stops walking)
But why?
Ah!!! Yahh!!!
(to the ticket man) Uh, yeah, a ticket for Kramer.
Oh, yeah. (snaps fingers) You know, I forgot my wallet.
Are you kidding me?
Come on, just look at me. Tell me I'm not Kramer.
Look, I'll drive out here tomorrow and I'll show the I.D. I got nothing to do all day.
Where's a phone?
Oh, God.
Jerry, I need another massage!
Because of the Giant game! I told you, It went overtime! You know what those seats are like. They're very unforgiving.
And then the game-winning field goal went over the net and into the crowd and I dove over three rows! My back, it's killing me! (whining) It's killing me Jerry!
Oh I got the ball.
Well, It's quite a thrill.
Because nobody does it like she does. She's the best.
What about my massage?

You can always tell what was the best year of your father's life, because they seem to just freeze that clothing style and just ride it out to the end, don't they? And it's not like they don't continue shopping, it's just they somehow manage to find new old clothes. Every father is like this fashion time capsule, you know what I mean. It's like they should be on a pedestal, with someone next to 'em going 'This was nineteen sixty-five'. To me the worst thing is shopping for pants. I hate dressing and undressing in that little room. What men need is a place to shop where you go in, you check your pants at the door, and you just walk around the store in your underwear. That would be the best way. Then you'd really have to lie to the salesman. 'Need some help?' 'No, just getting some air.'
How would you describe the smell in this house?
Yeah, that's part of it. (sniffs) Kasha?
Yeah. Dandruff, kasha, mothballs, cheap carpeting. It's pot pourri, really.
You're not allowed to have people over?
(picks it up) I was having coffee, I put it on the coffee table.
What's the big rush?
Who?
Eh, eh, ah. Winona's gonna be there?
(interested) Really?
Thanks, because I would really like... (distractedly puts coffee cup back on the table)
Alright, I'm sorry. I'm sorry. (picks it up again)
Just put a coffee table book over it.
There you go. That'll get you home in time.
I'm sorry Elaine, I'll make it up to you.
(handing her a magazine) Here, read this.
Hey, maybe I should get Elaine something.
Ah, you know, I didn't drive her home. Plus, I give her a gift in front of Winona, how does that hurt me?
What about, what about this thing?
Yeah. You know, kind of a peace offering. Cute.
Alright, I'll take it.
Surprise! (he carries in the object)
Well, I felt bad about this afternoon, so I got you something.
Hi. Hi Winona. Nice to see you again.
I don't need a reason to give gifts, it's my nature. I love to make people happy.
Are you ready?
(whips off bag to reveal Indian) Ta-da!
It's a cigar store Indian. (to Elaine) Read the card.
Read it out loud.
(takes the card from Elaine) We had a little fight this afternoon. (reading from card) Let's bury the hatchet. We smoke um peace pipe.
Hey-yah, ho-ah, hey-yah, ho-ah.
...ho-ah. It's, it's, it's kitschy.
She is?
Uh, Winona, it's Jerry Seinfeld.
Uhm, listen, I really felt bad about what happened, and I, I, I'd really like to apologise. Can I come up?
And well it should be. I think if you spent any time with me at all, you'd see I'm very sensitive to these matters as well. You wouldn't be hungry by any chance, wouldya?

You like Chinese food, 'cos I once went to a great Szechwan restaurant in this neighbourhood. I don't remember the exact address... (he spots a mailman crouched emptying a box) Uh, excuse me, you must know where the Chinese restaurant is around here.
I asked because you were the mailman, you would know the neighbourhood.
I didn't know that...
I, I had no idea.
Yeah, did a good job.

You know, I don't get it. Not allowed to ask a Chinese person where the Chinese restaurant is! I mean, aren't we all getting a little too sensitive? I mean, someone asks me which way is Israel, I don't fly off the handle.
Ah, she kinda calmed down. I talked to her today. In fact I'm gonna see her tonight.
Yeah, but I'm a little uncomfortable. I'm afraid of making another mistake.
Hello.
Uh, Elaine took it to read on the subway.
Wa, it's two weeks old.
You collect TV Guide?
I'll see you later. (he leaves with unseemly haste)
I thought we'd eat at the Gentle Harvest.
Ah, don't worry. I made reser... (catches himself)
I uh, I uh, I arranged for the appropriate accommodations. And then, Knick tickets, floor seats.
Got 'em on the street, from a scal... (catches himself again)
A uh, one of those guys.
You know, the guys, that uh, they sell the tickets for the sold-out events.
Wait a second, you got the Mark McEwan TV Guide.
Oh well, they're both chubby weathermen. I get Dom Deluise and Paul Prudhoe mixed up too. Could I have this?
Thanks.
So, Winona had the TV Guide. Told you I'd make it up to you.
Yeah. You almost ruined his life's work.
Yeah.
What'ya do with the one you took?
I thought it was a pretty good idea. It's about coffee tables, it's on a coffee table.
Where you going?
My Indian?
