I'm sorry I missed it.
Oh...pretty good.
Well, it's about Holly Go-Lightly.
Yeah, she's quite a character.
No.
I couldn't. You know, if it's not about sports, I find it very hard to concentrate.
No, I'm not. I would like to be, but I'm not. What am I gonna do? The book club meets in a few days.
'Why don't I rent the movie.' See, this is when I like you. Alright, now I'm relieved. (Kramer enters and comes over to the booth.)
I'd like to rent Breakfast At Tiffany's.
Out? Oh no, I've been to four other places, you're the only ones that have had it.
Maybe we could call them and ask them to return it.
Well, maybe they're done with it. I could go pick it up.
Uh, excuse me, are you Joe Temple?
Uh, yes, uh...you don't know me, my name is George Costanza...did you happen to rent Breakfast At Tiffany's?
Well, anyway, the book club meets tomorrow, Mr. Temple.
She was a delicate flower.
Well, as I say, the pink-eye made my vision...quite blurry... (Joe's daughter comes to the door.)
So, anything to uh, nosh?
Popcorn?
Well, a lot of people keep popcorn in the house.
You might want to try it...makes the movie more enjoyable, that's all.
Oh! Nuts! Excellent! You know what I love? How there's two nuts named after people. Hazel...and filbert.
Hey, let's turn off the lights, get some real 'movie atmosphere.'
You know, I'm sorry, I...I hate to be one of those people, but we're right in the middle of this thing...I can't hear.
Any more grape juice? (Gets up and goes to the kitchen. Remy moves to the end of the couch where George was sitting.)
So, we watching the movie, or are we still talking? (Joe's wife shakes her head and goes into the other room. George gestures to Remy to move.) Okay, c'mon. Let's go.
C'mon, you took my seat.
I was sitting there, c'mon.
I had the arm! Joe...
Well, I was very comfortable! I've got my nuts here...
Alright, c'mon, scooch over. (Tries to squeeze into the corner seat of the couch and struggles with Remy. He spills his glass of grape juice all over the couch in the process.)
Joe...
Well, not really. After all, she did get together with George Peppard. I mean, Fred.
Hey, what's going on?
New couch? Why?
Oh, let me get the door for you. (They carry the couch out the door.) Ooh, be careful!
What are you doing with your old couch?
Yeah, I'll take it.
Yes, they can. (Kramer enters.)
What was that again?
I heard Poppie's was good, let's go.
Ooh! I love duck. C'mon, c'mon!
Well, I don't know. I'll have to sit on it.
'Kay. You, uh...you got room in the truck for me?
Oh, goody. Okay, well uh...(to Jerry and Kramer)...I'll see you chumps later. (Elaine and Carl exit.)
So, he puts the couch down, and just as he's about to leave he says, "Do you date moving men?"
You wanna know what I said?
"I do now."
Is that something?
Is that something?
Well, they're real men, Jerry. They get sweaty.
Yes.
Nice to meet you, Poppie.
Well, your mother must be very proud of you.
Boy, I'm really looking forward to this duck. I've never had food ordered in advance before.
Paccino's? Oh no. You should never order pizza from Paccino's.
Because, the owner contributes a lot of money to those fanatical, anti-abortion groups.
No way.
Yeah.
Well, I guess I wouldn't eat here, then.
Yeah. That's right.
Nothing.
What's wrong with him?
Yeah. You're right.
Do you know that I have been using the same bottle of shampoo for a year? And I shampoo every day. (Carl smiles.) So, what do you think of my conversation?
You don't have any furniture?
Well, I can understand that. Pretty good date, huh?
I'm in looove!
This is it, Jerry! This is it! He is such an incredible person! He's real, he's honest, he's unpretentious...oh, I'm really lucky!
No, I forgot. And, the best part is, he doesn't play games. You know? There are no games! (Sits down on the couch.)
Well, I'm sure he's pro-choice.
Because he, well...he's just so good-looking.
Hi. (They kiss.)
Oh, I missed you!
Me, either!
You do?
Oh yeah, all the time, all the time...although, recently I've been thinking about this friend of mine.
Oh, just this woman...she got impregnated by her troglodytic half-brother, and decided to have an abortion. (Waits in suspense for what Carl's response will be.)
Oh my god.
So, you're gonna get a new couch?
Do you want your old couch back?
Who's that?
No, no, he's not my boyfriend.
Take a guess.
Hi.
Did you tell him it was peed on?
Yeah, me too.
Yeah. It is.
Can I offer you anything to drink?
Hey! Couch is comin.'
Alright! Yeah. You know, I'm excited about this, Jerry. In a way, I feel like I'm getting a new couch.
Ooh! Remember Poppie?
Yeah, yeah. Anyway, uh...we're going into business together. Remember that idea I had a few years ago about the pizza place where you make your own pizza?

It's a pizza place where you make your own pie! We give you the dough, the sauce, the cheese...you pound it, slap it, you flip it up into the air...you put your toppings on and you slide it into the oven! Sounds good, huh?
Well, I happened to be eating at Poppie's when I told him the "old" idea, and his eyes - waaaaaah! - just lit up. You know, he wants to back it.
That was in the past, Jerry. As it happens, New York Magazine just judged his kitchen to be one of the cleanest in the city. They got a duck there, you think you died and went to heaven.
Yeah, but you gotta order it two days in advance. (To Jerry) You know, I'm gonna call him, I'm gonna order the duck for you.
Did you offer those guys a drink?
What kind of a person are you?
Did you enjoy the duck? (Elaine comes back from the bathroom.) Oh, Elaine! I was just asking how dinner went last night.
Alright, what did you do to Poppie?
Well, he's in the hospital. And the cook says you put him there.
I don't know! I'm gonna go and visit him later. (angrily) It would be nice if you got him something. (Punches the the table to accentuate this, and leaves.)
Anyway, Jerry and Elaine felt very badly about what happened to you, and they wanted you to have this.
Why, what...?
Well, we're not very close.
Oh, they got good ducks there, huh?
Hey.
Well, you know, Poppie's over at my place. Tonight's the big night. I'm gonna make the first test pizza at the restaurant.
Yeah. Anyway, he's about to leave, he wants the duck money. (Poppie enters.)
Why don't you sit down, Poppie? You're still recuperating. (Poppie moves to the sofa and sits down, and exhales a loud sigh of relief.) What, are you tired, Poppie?
Hey, Poppie...you really think people wanna make their own pizza?
What is what?
What puddle?
I don't know.
Are you sure?
I'm sure it'll come out.
Ah, you're making too much of it.
Right!
And...cucumbers! (Grabs a large handful and puts them on the pizza.)
It's cucumbers.
Well, why not? I like cucumbers.
But that's the idea, you make your own pie.
What gives you the right to tell me how I would make my pie?
It's not a pizza until it comes out of the oven!
No, it isn't!

I've never been able to figure out why they make these bizarre toilet seats that they have. You know, like those clear Lucite ones, with all the, the coins in it? It's a lovely tribute to our past president, by the way. It's not bad enough Lincoln got shot in the head, we gotta pull down our pants and sit on him, too. It's just incomprehensible that you would buy a thing like this, you install it on your toilet seat, and this says what about you? "Well, I can't afford to just throw money down the toilet, but look how close I am!"
I cannot believe Lindsay's still seeing you after that "Breakfast at Tiffany's" thing.
As we all do.
Oh, so you're gonna meet the mother?
You're good with the mothers.
Maybe you should date the mothers.
Oh, you got something goin'.
What do you need a hammer for?
Oh, yeah! I wanna see that. Bring it over.
Nah, I don't think so.
Hey, could you wait until the man finishes?
Hey, guess what? Remember that woman you saw me with the other day? You know, she used to be an Olympic gymnast?
Yeah, she's Romanian, she won a silver at the '84 Olympics.
Yeah, well, I think I'm bailing.
Yeah, you know, Kramer, there's always a price to pay for just a sexual dalliance.
She's Romanian. What am I gonna talk to her about, Ceausescu?
(watching George buttoning his shirt) What is this?
(stares at George, incredulous) "Back on"? What was it doing off?
(laughing) What for?
Unbuttoned, or all the way off?
Of course.
What, again? Kramer, if you keep getting these attacks, you should see the doctor and have it checked out.
(picks up newspaper, turns to George) You always take the shirt off?
Boy, I tell ya', knowing you is like going out in the jungle. I never know what I'm going to find next, and I'm real scared.
(trying desperately to make conversation) So, Ceausescu. He must've been some dictator.
He, uh, he must've been dictating first thing in the morning. "I want a cup of coffee and a muffin!"
No, you'd have to be crazy.
Yes. Very bad. Very, very bad.
So lemme get this straight: you find yourself in the kitchen. You see an éclair, in the receptacle. And you think to yourself, "What the hell, I'll just eat some trash."
Was it in the trash?
Then it was trash.
But it was in the cylinder!
Adjacent to refuse, is refuse.
Was it eaten?
Well, that's garbage.
Well, you, my friend, have crossed the line that divides Man and Bum. You are now a Bum.
Hey!
What's with you?
What stone?
What is that, anyway?
Oh, that's gotta hurt.
Good for you.
Y'know what you should do now? Get her some flowers, smooth it out.
Kramer, are you still on this? I've seen gymnasts. I know what they do. It's not going to make any difference.
Kramer, y'know, guys like you, with no conscience, don't know what it's like for guys like me. I'm in the unfortunate position of having to consider people's feelings.
No.
No.
Boy, you can really talk some trash. (to George) I guess that's better than eating it.
All right.
(pointing at TV) Hey, that's her!
(smiling and excited) Well, here we are.
How did you stay on that beam like that? (holds up hand) I mean, it's only this wide!
Oh boy...
I couldn't believe it. Uh, I mean I thought I was entering a "magical world" of sensual delights, but it was just so ordinary. I mean, there was nothing gymnastic about it.
Well, you know. I mean... I dunno.
Well, obviously I prefer not to mention any, you know...
You see, now I really don't want to get into this, any kind of specifics...
Well... Frankly, I thought, you know, I was gonna kinda' be like the apparatus.
See, again, I really don't feel that...
Could we stop?
All right. Let's just drop it.
So lemme ask you this: how long would you say I have to put in now because of, you know, last night.
(sarcastic) Oh, great.
Between Poland and Morgan?
Kramer! The stone!
What happened, did you pass the stone?
Strike two!
You're behind in the count.
I'm going out with Katya, thanks to you.
If I do it again, that extends my payment book another two weeks.
We're going to the circus. One of her old Olympic teammates is an acrobat. I don't even feel like going out.
Yeah, well, y'know what? If I gotta go, and spend time with this girl, then you're coming with me, Dr. Cyclops!
Yeah, well you're going.
"Greatest Show on Earth"!
Well, they certainly take up a lot of space.
Well, break a leg.
Eh, show biz...
Boy, those capes are really coming back.
What is that sound?
Oh, why not?
Really?
I think she finds my stupidity charming.
Yeah, anyway, she's uh, having some kind of a family lunch, I'll swing by after.
Yeah, I'll zip in, "How do you do?", zip out. She'll love me.
Y'know, I'm better with the mothers than I am with the daughters.
Well, if I could talk to the mothers and have sex with the daughters, then I'd really have something goin'.
Yeah.
Hey! (heads toward bathroom)
(inside bathroom) Nah.
(emerging from bathroom, buttoning his shirt) A gymnast! I can't believe it, you didn't tell me she was a gymnast.
What, I'm puttin' my shirt back on.
I take it off when I go to the, uh, y'know, to the "office".
Well, it frees me up. No encumbrances.
ALL the way, baby!
Always.
Oh, no, no, not at all. No, I have always felt that the most important thing in the world is spending time with family.
(hesitates) Very close, yes. Almost painfully close.

Mind? Why would I mind? I would love to wait! (shakes hands with Nana) Nana, nice to see you. Ni-ni-ni-ni-NANA! (embraces another guest, kisses her) Aunt Phyllis, always a pleasure. What a pleasure! Hey, let's do this again real soon. I had fun, huh?
Oh, no no no, I'm fine. Let me help you with these dishes, huh?
No, I know I don't have to, I want to.
I'd argue if I could, Mrs. Enright. (exits) Here we go, all right.
(spits out mouthful of food): Mrs. Enright! Mrs. Enright!
No, no. No, no, no. It was not trash!
Yes.
It wasn't down in, it was sort of on top.
Above the rim.
It was on a magazine! And it still had the doily on.
One little bite.
But I know who took the bite. It was her aunt!

(on phone, as Jerry gestures beside him) No, Lindsay, it was not IN the garbage. It was above the garbage. Hovering. Like an angel. Of course I know your aunt bit it. I kissed her goodbye. Listen, can I tell you something else? In my family, we used to eat out of the garbage all the time. (Jerry makes a face) It was no big thing. That's right. Oh, okay. Buh-bye. (hangs up phone) I'm back in, she gave me a second chance.
Yes, good for me!
Yes, flowers. I will get her flowers, I will go to the florist!
Did you pass your stone yet?

(singing as he exits florist with bouquet and a cup of coffee) "...tootsie, good-bye. Too-too, tootsie..." (takes a drink, makes a face, shouts back at shop) You call this coffee? (dumps out coffee behind him, accidentally hitting a parked car's windshield)
I'm sorry! I'm terribly sorry! I- I-

Oh, sure. Of course. (looks for place to set down flowers) Um, uh, could you hold these? For just a second, just a second. (grabs newspapers from trash bin, begins wiping windshield) Here you go, now don't worry about a thing. It's gonna be fine. Here we go. Look at this shine.
Look at this sparkle. (looks up, sees Lindsay's mother) Mrs. Enright! (runs after her) Mrs. Enright! Mrs. Enright!

(on phone, as Jerry gestures beside him) No, Lindsay, I had accidentally spilled coffee on the gentleman's windshield. Why would I do that? I have a job! Well, did she see a squeegee? Well, you're not going to make a dime without a squeegee. That's right, that's right, just tell your mother it was all a big misunderstanding. You won't regret it. Okay, I'll see you later. Buh-bye. (hangs up)
You think I'm going down?
I know.
Well, here we are.
Maybe I could just use the bathroom.
Whew! Anybody see that poster in there? That is weird, wild stuff, huh? Whew!
What meeting?
Oh! (tries to take paper)
Yes?
All right! I'll use a pencil, Mr. Pitt.
Come in, come in!
Ah, right there, yeah.
Kramer, it's...
Kramer, Kramer, can you do this at home? I've got, I've got work to do, okay?
Okay, Kramer, that's enough. Mr. Pitt has got work to do.
Kramer, what's wrong?
Kramer, Kramer, are you okay?
(pointing at 3-D picture) Look, there's a spaceship! That is so cool!
(pointing) Right here.
No, no, unfocus.
(answering phone) Hello? Oh, yeah, okay fine. Uh, he'll be right down. (to Pitt) Car's here to pick you up and take you to the meeting.
Yeah, the Poland Creek merger?
How can I go?
Mr. Pitt, I do not think that is such a good idea.
Ah. The "stock swap". Let's swap some stock. (giggles)
All right. (standing up) Hey, you guys--what's the name of the new company gonna be?
(making a face) "Moland"?
Yeah, I know, but... "Moland"? I wouldn't drink anything called "Moland".
Oh! Well, ah, what's in a name? I mean, water's water. Right?
Well, what did you think she was gonna do?
No, what?
What did you think, she was going to take some of that chalk and...
Oh, come on. One thing? One thing! What?
The balance beam?
(gasps in mock surprise) Not the pommel horse?
I dunno, at least three weeks.
Jerry, that is such small potatoes. I think that I may have single-handedly put the kibosh on the big water merger.
Yeah. Started a big name controversy.
Well, I couldn't help it. "Moland Spring"?
Well, I'm so sorry! I-
Oh, sorry. (picks up phone) Hello?
(on phone) Oh, yes, yes I'll tell him. Yes, thank you. Um, um hold on. (to Pitt) Mr. Pitt!
Mr. Pitt! The board of directors is on the phone. They've called an emergency meeting. They want you to be there to discuss the merger!

(on phone) Yes, hi. Okay, fine, yeah, hold on just a second. Lemme just... (reaches into purse) Yeah, I've got it... (pulls out both hands completely covered in black ink) Oh! Oh! Yeah, yeah, he'll be there. (drops phone, rushes to Pitt) Mr. Pitt, you have GOT to stop staring at that poster!

(grabs poster, smashes it) No, you don't see it, and you're never going to see it! (grabs Pitt by the lapels, getting ink all over his jacket) Mr. Pitt, you have to meet with the shareholders, you have to leave now. Do you hear me? Do you hear me?!
In about twenty minutes.
Um, no.
Uh, Mr. Pitt...
Um, there's a just... (points at her own upper lip)
No?
(enters apartment) Hey.
Hey, you got a hammer?
Well, I got this new poster. 3-D art? Computers generate 'em.
No, no, I don't have it now. I gotta pick it up at Mr. Pitt's. Elaine was framing a bunch of stuff for him, so she did me a favor. What, you wanna take a ride?
(shouting to the bathroom door) George, you wanna go for a ride?
Oh, COME ON!
All right, I've had it with you two. (opens apartment door to leave)
A gymnast!
A gymnast, Jerry. Think of the flexibility. Mmm, that sex'll melt your face.
(shuts door) "Bailing"?
Jerry, you should pay that price.
Ch- oo-... what?
(convulses in pain) Yeow! Whoa.
(exiting apartment) Yeah, yeah, yeah...
Elaine?
Yeah. (enters, points at package) Yah, huh?
(rips open package) Yeah, that's...
(holds up framed picture): There she blows! (throws paper around)
Oh, these are nice corners, huh?
(looking at picture) Yeah, it's 3-D art. Computers generate 'em. BIG computers.
Well, you blur your eyes like you're starin' straight through the picture. And you keep your eyes unfocused. And then... (Kramer and Pitt stare at picture) Oh, oh, oh, YEAH!
Yeah, it's a spaceship, surrounded by planets, asteroids...
Ya' ever dream in 3-D? It's like the boogeyman is comin' right at you.
(pointing) Right in here. Just keep your eyes unfocused. (convulses in pain) Waahh! Oh, mama!
Mama!
I think I gotta go to the doctor! (exits) Oh, mama!
Hey.
I got a stone.
A kidney stone.
It's a, it's a stony mineral concretion, formed abnormally in the kidney. And this jagged shard of calcium pushes its way through the ureter into the bladder. It's forced out through the urine!
(enters apartment, holding up videotape) Behold! The Games of the '84 Olympiad! Katya's silver medal performance! (inserts tape into VCR, sets up TV)
Jerry, what is your problem?
All right, Jerry--are you familiar with the Kama Sutra?
Tantric yoga?
Jerry, you stand on the threshold to the magical world of sensual delights that most men dare not dream of!
All right, all right, why don't we just watch the tape? (starts playback)
Not yet. But the suspense is killing me.

Oh yeah. Oh yeah, that's her. (feminine grunts and sighs can be heard as they watch the tape) Look at the height, Jerry, the extension! Now watch the tuck. Handstand, half-turn, giant into a straddle, back into another handstand. Nice kip. Reverse hecht. Oh, nice leg extension, good form! Now, here comes the big dismount. Look at the rotation, full in, double back, and she sticks the landing! (gets up to leave as George and Jerry continue to watch, mouths agape) Perhaps you'd like to keep the tape? (silence) Well, I'll take that as a yes.
You mean like the uneven parallel bars?
(Off-screen) No, I tried to do a reverse hecht off my couch and I didn't make it.
(enters apartment, points at Jerry) Hey, what are you doing later?
Well, maybe you should try again. You know what happens the first time: people are a little shy, a little reticent.
All right, where you going?
Well, Jerry, it's your obligation. C'mon.
No, no, no, I don't wanna go to the circus, Jerry.
Yeah, but I'm afraid of clowns!
Ill have the, ah, turkey club without the bacon.
She does have a way.
Well they do work on tips.
Ah, I should have got the egg white omelet.
The omelet. Damn.
No.
Not possible.
Lannie, how was the trip?
Yeah, well that relationships really got a lot of potential.
Oh no, it's Kenny Bania.
(quietly) Oh, he's this awful comedian.
Hey Kenny. (with some fake enthusiasm, just to be polite)
Elaine, George (introducing them to Bania with less enthusiasm)
How's it going?
No kidding.
All right.
Ahh, Im a 40. Why?
Well I don't know if I ...
Well ... ok, I guess (voice trailing off)
Yeah.
Yeah, yeah, lucky me. (sips coffee)
Well, go in there and talk to her. She's not going to put em on the glass.
Pull yourself together. Your going in there soldier! That's an order!
Get in there. (he pushes George in the direction of the restaurant)
Hey.
What?
Why?
YEAH? (speaking loudly so the visitor can hear him through the intercom)
ALL RIGHT, COME ON UP (Jerry puts his head down - he's not looking forward to Kenny Bania)
Well, well, why are you getting rid of your refrigerator? (he gets up from the table and carries a dish into the kitchen)
What for?
Yeah.
Yes, yes, I heard.
No, it's ok.
All right, all right. (trying on the suit jacket)
Ok, Yeah all right.
Yes, yes, he is.
Dinner?
Yeah, Ill see you.
Yeah, that's a deal. That's a terrible deal. I don't want to go out to dinner with him. Id rather make my own suit.
Hey. (raises hands into fists of encouragement)
I love the day date. No wine, No shower.
So you just pretended it didnt bother you?
Boy, It's the way they just slip it in there too.
Well let me ask you this. What exactly did you say when you asked her out?
Oh, a walk, well --
Or something. Yeah, that's a date.
Course you know there is always the possibility, that she called an audible.
Well she got up to the line of scrimmage, didnt like the looks of the defense and changed the play.
Uh huh.
You did?
Yeah. You said you liked horse manure.
(quietly) Mm-hm.
And it was around this point that she mentioned the boyfriend?
Im just saying there's a chance she may not have been enamored with your thoughts and feelings on manure.
My honest opinion, I think she made it up.
Aaa. Well ... you want something to eat, don't you?
Well Im glad it's working out.
Boy, if I could meet a hostess, we could open up our own place.
Is she?
Hello?
Oh, Hi.
Yeah, you wanna get that meal, don't you?
No I haven't?
All right.
(hangs up the phone) Yeah, I really needed that suit.
Mm. That's fantastic. (he could care less)
No I don't.
Why?
No, not yet.
Ill have the salmon.
Another time? What other time?
No, no, Bania, no. This is the dinner. The soup counts.
Im not stopping you from eating. Go ahead and eat. Get anything you want.
Then that's the meal.
I didnt tell you to have a hot dog. Who told you to have a hot dog?
All right, fine. Get the soup!
So he just gets soup. He wants to save the meal. So now I got to do it all over again.
I don't know? Consommé or something.
What?
Elaine you're missing the whole point.
The meal is the act of sitting down with him. It doesn't matter what you get, as long as he's sitting in that restaurant, its a meal.
You see -- ah, uh ...
A bowl, ok?
As a mater of fact, he did.
It's like Im talking to my Aunt Sylvia here.
Well, I have some money. What do you need? (pulls out some bills)
So is she working? Is she here?
Have you said anything to her?
Are you going to say anything?
Ill have an egg white omelet.
Yeah, that was bad.
Oh, no, it's Kenny. Slide out so he can't sit down. (George & Jerry each slide to the end of their booth seats)
Hey.
Actually, I did. I put it on last night and slept in it.
... Oh, Im joking.
Why don't you get a sandwich?
OK ... (nodding his head up and down) This is it cha know
This is the meal ... so stock up buddy boy.
Yes it is. Soup and sandwich. That is a meal.
I tried to do that.
Doesn't matter, This is it. This completes the transaction.
Hi.
Where's Simon?
When's he leaving? (putting some items into the refrigerator)
Ah, no thanks.

(on the phone) Hello? No, Im sorry Bania ... Im not going over this again. Well who told you to order soup? ... No! There's no dinner. There's not going to be any dinner. You've had a sandwich and 2 bowls of soup and that's it. Good-bye.
Hey, what size suit are you?
40. Perfect. Brand-new Armani suit, you want it?
Great, its yours. I can't stand the sight of it. Elaine, heres the car keys. (tosses her the keys)
Yo?
I don't have your suit. I gave it away.
Well it's gone. Im sorry. Good-bye Bania.
Hey.
Ok.
Nothing.
You want food, don't cha? (nodding his head up and down)
All right, go ahead
What are we doing out here? Aren't we going to go in and eat?
Oh, w-what are you saying? So we're not going to go in there anymore?
We can't eat here anymore, because he took a waitress out for a walk.
So what's going on with Simon? Did he leave?
Look at this. They make a point of saying on the menu, No egg white omelets. Look at that.
Oh, hi Hilde. Can I get an egg white omelet?
All right, just give me a western. (unhappy)
Not fair.
She's on your turf.
You're the best.
Well as I see it, you've got to apply the same principles that get you fired, but redirected, outwardly.
Well, there's nothing left. There's no food.
Why'd she get fired?
Boy, he's a real bounder, isn't he?
I don't have it. You want half my omelet? (holds his omelet plate up to Bania)
And ah, Ill have the bacon club without the turkey. (raises eyebrows)
Why, you think you can, beat me up?

You mean a walk back in? That's the toughest move in the business. You're sending me out into no-mans-land, and if I get shot down I have to crawl all the way back. Well I can't do it! I can't do it, I tell ya!

I said, would you like to go for a walk or something.
Or something. I said, Or Something!
(snaps fingers) There you go.
What do you mean?
I think things were going ok. We were having a nice conversation.
I mentioned how I liked horse manure.
Yeah.
Yeah.
You know, about how when you break it down, it's really a very positive thing. you know, you have a nure, with a ma in front of it. MA-NURE. Iz not bad.

Hello.

What's it gonna be? ... You hear that?

Sure you can.
Yeah.

It's the same menu.
They'll make you a Big Salad. What do you think, they're the only one's that make a Big Salad?
So what! Have a yoke! It won't kill you.
Just tell her whatcha want, they'll make it for ya.
I mean, it's not fair. I've been going there for 7 years. She's been there 3 weeks.
If anyone should be forced to leave that place, it should be her!
If only she could get fired. Is there any way that could happen? I mean I know how to get myself fired.
Well ...... but how do I get someone else fired?
Heyyyyyy (leaning in, very friendly and happy)
I went to England ... with Mr. Pitt, for 5 days.
Actually it was great. I met an Englishman, and we really, hit it off.

It's an open ended ticket. He can return any time he wants.
Hi. (she flips her hair)

An Armani suit?
So the trip was good?

What?

Nothing.

Consommé, hmm.
Well, that's not really a meal Jerry. I mean, if he had gotten, Chicken Gumbo, or Matzah Ball, even Mushroom Barley. Then I would agree with you. Those are very hardy soups.
What?
Was it a cup or a bowl?
Im just curious.
Did he crumble any crackers in it?
(reiterating the question) Did he crumble, any crackers in it?

Oh, hi Simon. This is Jerry.
Um, yeah in my purse.
Where you going?
Oh, OK, see you later.
(English accent) Pardon?
Hi.
Oh, he'll be right up. He's just getting some beer. And Im not expecting ... any change. (leans forward as she brings her hands together in front of her, then sits on the couch)
About 2 days. Although he's hinting at how he'd like to stay. Fortunately he has no money, and no prospects. (she smiles)
Thanks
Hey, What are you doing out here?
Reggies? I can't eat anything there.

How bout a Big Salad?
(to George) Ya see?

Could you put it in a big bowl?

So, Simon is definitely going back now. He's meeting me here to return my keys.

Ah (hu ha - small laugh)

Listen, I need you to do me a favor.
Well, I need you to help me move my refrigerator.

(claps hands) So ...
Well after that Kidney Stone I only want fresh food. It's gotta be fresh. Im not eating any more stored food. Plus you know I want the space.
Well I could put a, dresser in there. I could get dressed while Im making breakfast.

And Barbara Mandrell's skateboard!

You really seemed to enjoy it.

Yeah...

Which word did he emphasize? Did he say, "Why would Jerry bring anything?" or, "Why would Jerry bring anything?" You emphasize "Jerry" or "bring."

No, I don't know if I'm invited.
Yeah, you're right.

Oh, please.

Elaine, would you marry me?
Alright. Forget it.
Hey, Tim.

Just a quick peek. I'm in agony.
Especially that big kid up in the front. (Mr. Pitt is shown on the television, trying to hold up the deflating Woody balloon.) How old is he? (The phone rings.) Hello?
Yes it is.
Can I have the address of that garage sale? Okay, thank you very much. (To Kramer) I found Mom and Pop, they're sellin' my sneakers!
Parsippany, New Jersey.
My car's in the shop.

No, I decided to go with an '89 LeBaron.
What Consumer? I'm the consumer.

I like (imitates Kramer) "cookies."

You are gonna love this car. Even if you don't like Jon Voight.

Well, why would the guy make up something like that? Of all the names he could pick, why settle on Jon Voight?

So?

Get out!
Get out!! (Jerry gets out and George drives away. A couple of guys notice Jerry in his cowboy boots.)

Anyway, again, I'm sorry about throwing you out of the car.

Well, I think we need more special days at the stadium, you know? Like, uh...Joe Pepitone Day. Or, uh...Jon Voight Day.

Artie Shaw. "Honeysuckle Jump." (The song ends.)

Will you shut up? I can't hear!

What? I can't hear you.
I told you, I can't hear a word.
Tim.

Hey.

Well, he's got a Peter Pan complex.

Yeah. (Lies on the couch and cracks the back of his head against the armrest.) Hey, what's with your ceiling? (Mom and Pop look up.)

Well, obviously there was a miscommunication.
Jerry, I left you a pair right here...(goes into Jerry's room and comes out with a pair of cowboy boots.) C'mon. There, put on those boots.

C'mon here, try 'em on. (Jerry sits down and puts the boots on.)
Ah, you look like a cowboy! Huh?

Yeah?
Not necessarily.

Hey.
That's what I wanna know.
Well, I saw Mom and Pop this morning, but when I went by the store on my way home? The place was empty. Everything is gone. Mom and Pop - vrooop - vanished.

It was all an act, Jerry. They conned us, and they scored, big time.
Apparently.
Oh. Oh man. (Takes out a Kleenex and puts his head back. Jon Voight comes out of a doorway and hails a cab.)

Listen, listen...(Leans in the the open back window of the cab. Defensively, Voight grabs Kramer's arm and bites it. Kramer screams. The cab speeds off leaving Kramer in the street, stunned.)
No. (To George) But I did run into somebody you might be interested in, a Mr. Jon Voight, the actor?
Well, he was a little standoffish.
No, I couldn't, his cab pulled away. But he did, however, make an impression on me. (Pulls up his sleeve and shows George his arm.) Look.
His tooth marks. He bit me.
No, it's justifiable. He thought I was going for his wallet.
That he did. Now, you got that pencil with the bite marks on it? We get a trained eye to match 'em up, and we'll see whether or not you're driving Jon Voight's car!
Jerry, look, come on, I'm an invited guest. I can't be aiding and abetting some...party-crasher.
You got a problem with Woody Woodpecker?
That's right. He's a troublemaker.
He didn't come with us. (Tim walks over to Jerry.)
Not just someone. Jon Voight.
Oh! You popped Woody Woodpecker!
Those kids look pretty disappointed.
Where are they?
Let's go!
Well, how are we getting to Parsippany?
Uh. Jerry. These nosebleeds are starting again.
That's incredible. Six months ago you were taking messages for your mother.
From your mother.
So this ah, woman you plan on hiring, is she going to be in the Spokes model category?
That's a 180, George.
Hi Willie.
I got this stuff and ah my mother's fur coat for storage.
Ah, she keeps it in my apartment for when she comes up from Florida.
Hi.
Yeah, that's why I said hi.
Thanks. It's Hounds-Tooth.
Oh yes, it really accentuates my bust line.
Yeah.
So you're saying, Store -- Hotsy-Totsy, Home-- Hotsy-Notsy.
I thought we were going to the movies?
Because you didnt have a job?
A lesser man would have crumbled. They would have gone for the dish and the sure fire sexual-harassment suit.
It's a little ...
You got no waist in that thing.
How fast was she walking?
No. I think it's Demi. (the "i" sounds like an "e")
What?
Oh, you're crazy.
Do it tomorrow. Well go to the movies.
Well, that was the worst.
Yeah, I think I do.
Well, all I got is my dry-cleaning stub.
Uma Therman? Really?
He's got the Kavorca. (looking towards the theater door, Jerry notices one of the movie goers) Hey, isn't that Willie, my dry-cleaner?
He just went in. You know, I think he was wearing my Hounds-Tooth jacket.
It looked just like the jacket I brought in to be dry-cleaned. He complimented me on it.
So you're having sex and then all of a sudden, you just blurt out Im giving you a raise.
Just a quick sidebar here -- are you in anyway authorized to give raises?
So you're so grateful to have sex, that you'll just shout out anything that comes into your head.
Well maybe she'll just think it was bawdy talk.
Maybe you could have sex with her again and then take it back.
All right, all right. Im sorry.
How long has she been there?
It's almost a week.
Oh, My god.
It's a movie stub from the 9:30 show. George, I think Willie the dry-cleaner has been wearing my clothes.
Hello, Willie.
No, but ah, seen any good movies lately?
Yeah. Specifically 9:30 shows. Seen any good 9:30 shows at the Paragon, Willie?
I saw you the other night stepping out with my Hounds-Tooth jacket.
You need a code to tell you not to wear peoples clothes
Yeahhh, am I imagining this? (he whips out the movie stub and holds it up to Willie) Found this little cutie in the pocket. (throws the stub on the counter)
Yeah, Yeah. Well, now that we understand each other -- Ill be taking my business elsewhere. And I want my mother's fur coat back too.
Now.

Where's that ticket? Oh, Kramer.
No, not on me.
Why? I've got my cleaning before without a ticket.
All right, Ill be back.
(to the Barneys sales associate) Excuse me, could you tell me where I could find, like, women's moisturizer lotions?
Kramer?
What clothes?
No.

Where are your pants?
What? You sold your pants to Bania. Let me in.
Why'd you sell your pants to Bania?
Where are your clothes?
You mean what you were wearing?
How'd you expect to get out of here?
[Elaine]
Im going out. (he comes out of the dressing room, while Kramer remains inside)
Bania.
(to Bania) Excuse me. (he goes back in the dressing room)
Never mind Uma, I need that ticket to get my mother's fur coat back. Why don't you just give him the money for the suit?
I got an idea.
I cant believe Im gonna do this. (Jerry opens the door and exits the dressing room. He walks over to Bania)
Bania can I talk to you for a second? How's everything going?

Yeah, well, see the thing of it is, Im in a bit of an awkward position here. Because, uhh, I don't want to get in between you two guys but ... I need a dry-cleaning ticket that's in the pocket of those pants.
Yeah, yeah all right, well uh ... tell you what I will do Bania -- you give me the ticket, and uh, I will take you out for a nice dinner.
You want to go to Mendys, Ill take you to Mendys.
all right lets be reasonable, Bania. Im taking you out for a nice dinner. All I want is a little ticket in that pocket. I think it's a pretty good deal.
. . . All right (gritting teeth) Just give me the ticket.
Ohh ... (takes the ticket and heads for the dressing room)
Let me in, it's me. (Kramer opens the door, Jerry goes in the dressing room) Here. You don't know what this is costing me. (hands Kramer the ticket)
(Takes the ticket back and looks at it, flips it over) The dry-cleaning numbers are gone too.
(grabs the ticket back) Give me that.

What time does your flight get in? Six? All right, that gives us six hours. Then I'll meet you at the diplomat's club. I'll be the one without the big red sash. Okay, see you tonight. (Hangs up)

I don't have a preference, okay! Just make a decision yourself! Stop bothering me with every minor little detail, please?
George.
I'm still here. Listen, you gotta go down to the Diplomat's Club...

Defent.

Mr. Pitt...

(Flattered) Mr. Pitt...

Kramer.

Oh I'm happy right here. Isn't this place amazing? Planes flying in from all corners of the world, and they know the minute they're arriving.

Boy...

Siena?

Yeah.

I mean, what compels a seemingly normal human being to do something like that?
You know I really hate my clothes.
I open up my closet, there's just nothing.
Nothing. I hate everything I have, I really hate it. (The weeping increases in volume and intensity) I mean, at this point, it's like I can wear something three or four times and that's it.
It's getting to be a terrible problem for me.

David? David, I think we aught to talk.
David, I don't think we should see each other anymore.
Well, you see, David, you're a face painter.

Yeah, but you like the face painting.
Oh. You mean you'd stop it for me?
That's so, that's so sweet.
What is that?
Why is the letter 'D' painted on your chest?
But you said no more painting.

Hey.

Hey.

Alright, that's enough out of you, there's still three more games left in this series, my friend, and it's far from being over. Very far from being over. (Notices a car coming right towards Puddy, who's crossing the street) Watch out!

So no hard feelings?
Well? Did he call?

yeah,

Aaaaaah

uh, ha.
